messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Q on Kunihiro tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, I don t think that there is any connection with the Ito school.  Bushu is of course the other name for Musashi province, where Edo/Tokyo is located.
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
I don't think that there is any connection with the Ito school. Bushu is of course the other name for Musashi province, where Edo/Tokyo is located. There were many fitting makers living in Bushu.

Given the variation in the Kunihiro signatures and the quality of the work there may have been more than one person making those tsuba. Haynes proposes 4 or 5 makers working over the course of 100 years in his Index of Japanese Sword Fittings and Associated Artists.

Jim



Jim -

Thanks for the pics. Do I assume that even though he signed
Bushu ju, that he was not a member of the Bushu Ito school?
I don't recall seeing anything on him in my Ito school books.

Rich S


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Satsuma Rebellion mountings
messages.msgSnippet: Also here s another link to a photo of this type of koshirae for anyone not familiar with it:
messages.messageBody:
Also here's another link to a photo of this type of koshirae for anyone not familiar with it:

http://www.japanesesword.com/Images/Swords/02/602/602wak2/signed_satsuma_rebellion_wakizas.htm

Jim

Dear Friends,
Please let me ask a question about a style of koshirae, even if I
suspects that it falls well below the standards of most those on this
list.
I am suddenly, and I hopefully briefly, interested in so-called
"Satsuma rebellion" fittings. I recall seeing these over the years, but
never had a term for them until Fuller and Gregory published a couple of
pages about them in their first volume on "Imperial swords." In that book,
they say - without reference - that the samurai army raised against the
newly formed Imperial Army of the Meiji government by Saigo Takamori was
equipped with swords that have a distinctive flat wrap and very ordinary
kodogu. Notably, they often have simple washer style menuki.
There is no question that these fittings are a "type" that does occur
in the real world. By that I mean that it is a fairly consistent style that
we do see it from time to time. It looks expedient and very
"utility-grade." But is anyone really aware of evidence that they really
were associated with the Satsuma Rebellion? I'm wondering if they might
simply be very low-end koshirae produced in terminal Edo/Meiji times for
any market there was for low-end swords. If any one has insights on this, I
would appreciate them. Thnak you
I might as well explain why I ask. I recently acquired some (about
140 in all ) 1910 vintage photos of North Pacific ethnographic objects that
were being sold by a dealer. A couple of these pictures show Japanese
swords and at least one of them certainly looks like a "Rebellion sword." I
know the Rebellion failed, but I have a hard time believing that Saigo left
Kyushu for the Aleutians!
Peter



Peter Bleed
Associate Dean
College of Arts and Sciences
1223 Oldfather Hall
University of Nebraska
Lincoln, NE 68588-0312
(402) 472-2891

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Satsuma Rebellion mountings
messages.msgSnippet: Peter, Given the uniformity of that style of koshirae I d suspect that they were assembled in a fairly narrow space of time and place rather than being a
messages.messageBody:
Peter,
Given the uniformity of that style of koshirae I'd suspect that they were assembled in a fairly narrow space of time and place rather than being a general style of late, low quality mount. They give the impression of being made for imminent use rather than routine daily wear. The Satsuma rebellion label seems plausible, but I don't know of any hard evidence supporting F&G's attribution. For what it's worth, the book published last year on Satsuma koshirae does not include any illustrations of this type of mount.

On the subject of your photos, I've seen a lot of references to George I. Quimby's 1985 paper "Japanese Wrecks, Iron Tools, and Prehistoric Indians of the Northwest Coast" published in Arctic Anthropology 22(2):7-15. I haven't read it, but it might be of interest.

Here is a link to an interesting on-line article from the Royal British Columbian Museum web site that disputes Quimby but does cite intentional and unintentional travel by pre-20th C Japanese to the western coast of the Americas:

http://rbcm1.rbcm.gov.bc.ca/hhistory/japaneseshipwrecks/toc.html

Jim

Peter

messages.subject: Q on Kunihiro tsuba [A decorated example]
messages.msgSnippet: Rich and all, I ve placed a couple of photos of a more decorated example of Kunihiro tsuba in my folder ( Craig s ) along with the hakogaki.
messages.messageBody:
Rich and all,

I've placed a couple of photos of a more decorated example of Kunihiro tsuba
in my folder ("Craig's") along with the hakogaki.

http://tinyurl.com/2v4fu

Jim might want to comment on the hakogaki by Dr. Torigoye.

Craig Harris


-----Original Message-----
From: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
Sent: Monday, March 08, 2004 4:01 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Q on Kunihiro tsuba


Rich,
Here are a few sukashi examples:
http://tinyurl.com/294el

I've also seen some with a signaling conch motif. I have seen one or two
with some relief carving and very simple inlay.

Some of the signed plain plates have had lacquer decoration added later, not
by Kunihiro.

Jim



I've seen a lot of plain iron tsuba, mostly round occasionally
mokko, signed Kunihiro. Never seen one with any sukashi, carving
or inlay. Did he do anything other than plain iron?

Thanks
Rich S

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Satsuma Rebellion mountings
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Pete - ... By no means, Pete, an interesting subject. It would be so interesting to see perhaps a dozen or two examples of this kind of mountings pulled
messages.messageBody:
Hi Pete -

>even if I suspects that it falls well below the >standards of most those on this list...

By no means, Pete, an interesting subject. It would be so interesting to see perhaps a dozen or two examples of this kind of mountings pulled together into a well illustrated article and some research by which to draw some conclusions. Too often these "original" era mountings are pulled apart because they are so utilitarian when in reality, they are examples "of the era" that should be preserved. I have one such mounting at this time and do plan on preserving it intact.

As an aside...did you get my email about the arrowhead menuki that I sent a few days ago???

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Peter A Bleed
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, March 08, 2004 5:26 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Satsuma Rebellion mountings






Dear Friends,
Please let me ask a question about a style of koshirae, even if I
suspects that it falls well below the standards of most those on this
list.
I am suddenly, and I hopefully briefly, interested in so-called
"Satsuma rebellion" fittings. I recall seeing these over the years, but
never had a term for them until Fuller and Gregory published a couple of
pages about them in their first volume on "Imperial swords." In that book,
they say - without reference - that the samurai army raised against the
newly formed Imperial Army of the Meiji government by Saigo Takamori was
equipped with swords that have a distinctive flat wrap and very ordinary
kodogu. Notably, they often have simple washer style menuki.
There is no question that these fittings are a "type" that does occur
in the real world. By that I mean that it is a fairly consistent style that
we do see it from time to time. It looks expedient and very
"utility-grade." But is anyone really aware of evidence that they really
were associated with the Satsuma Rebellion? I'm wondering if they might
simply be very low-end koshirae produced in terminal Edo/Meiji times for
any market there was for low-end swords. If any one has insights on this, I
would appreciate them. Thnak you
I might as well explain why I ask. I recently acquired some (about
140 in all ) 1910 vintage photos of North Pacific ethnographic objects that
were being sold by a dealer. A couple of these pictures show Japanese
swords and at least one of them certainly looks like a "Rebellion sword." I
know the Rebellion failed, but I have a hard time believing that Saigo left
Kyushu for the Aleutians!
Peter

messages.msgSnippet: Rich, Here are a few sukashi examples: http://tinyurl.com/294el I ve also seen some with a signaling conch motif.  I have seen one or two with some relief
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
Here are a few sukashi examples:
http://tinyurl.com/294el

I've also seen some with a signaling conch motif. I have seen one or two with some relief carving and very simple inlay.

Some of the signed plain plates have had lacquer decoration added later, not by Kunihiro.

Jim



I've seen a lot of plain iron tsuba, mostly round occasionally
mokko, signed Kunihiro. Never seen one with any sukashi, carving
or inlay. Did he do anything other than plain iron?

Thanks
Rich S
